And Florida, too, is struggling with voting issues.
Eight years after the infamous hanging chads election, Florida is again mired in voting controversy.
Damien Cave writes about this in today's New York Times, and he's here now.
Welcome to the program.

Well, you write in your story that it is now harder to vote here than in nearly every other state in the nation.
Why is that?
Well, what happened is, after the 2000 election, several states created a series of laws or policies to secure the voting system, and Florida ended up on the far end of the spectrum.
So, at this point, you have a handful of laws.
One that manages third-party voter registration groups and makes it harder, a little bit, for them to do their jobs.
Another one that makes it harder for voters to have their vote counted, if there's a mistake on their voter registration form.
And there's a third one that doesn't allow people to correct mistakes on their voter registration form within a month of the election.
So, taken together, these laws, many voting rights advocates argue, make Florida one of the most difficult states to vote, to register to vote and to get your vote counted.
Well, taking all three of these provisions in a little more detail, what do the proponents say?
Why do they say that Florida needs these?
Well, some of the law makers that I talked to said that Florida needs to err on the side of caution because of what happened in 2000.
And that the idea is to create some kind of more transparent system, so that it's very clear on election day, this is what's counted, and this is what's not.
You know, the question is whether or not, that kind of transparency will actually happen, in the midst of a heated or close election.
And so why do the opponents of these, why do they think that it will unfairly exclude minorities, poor people, older people?
Well, speaking just to the idea of third-party voter registration groups, most of these groups focus on generally under-represented groups, which tend to be Hispanics, blacks, or old people.

That's plenty of time, and they shouldn't lose forms.
This is very important, and these groups acknowledge that.
The issue is that, for many of them, they do internal quality control, where they make phone calls to make sure that the accuracy of what's been written is correct, and they also have volunteers.
